In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Certainly! Below is the implementation of the `timezone_bumper` function in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Int=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(dt::Date, bump::Int=3)
    throw(ArgumentError("Function only works for DateTime types"))
end
```

You can use this function to increase the timestamp of a given DateTime object by a specified number of hours. If you pass a Date object to the function, it will throw an error as per the specified requirement.
